Course Overview
We will consider three topics in normative ethics: hope, trust, and forgiveness. The task is to clarify {a} your sense of the basic character of each phenomenon, {b} its relative value, and {c} how it functions in ethical life.
 Principal Course Objectives
o	To help you clarify your own conceptions of hope, trust, & forgiveness.
o	To enable you, in writing and orally, to cogently discuss, compare, contrast, and evaluate a variety of philosophical accounts of hope, trust, and forgiveness.
o To increase your ability to present and critically engage your own ideas in your own language.
Secondary Course Objectives
o	By the end of the course, you should be able to: 
o	recognize and pursues various modes of ethics as a philosophical subdiscipline,
o	concretely engage various modes of philosophical inquiry and presentation,
o	effectively engage primary and secondary philosophical literature in the course of your research and writing.
course_description: This course will investigate moral theories as presented by their famous proponents, including such topics as virtue ethics, deontology, and utilitarianism.
prerequisites: Two PHIL courses or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.
